{{Infobox planet | minorplanet=yes | background=#D6D6D6 | name=333 Badenia | discoverer=[[Max Wolf]] | discovered=22 August 1892 | mpc_name=(333) Badenia | alt_names=1892 A, A895 DC,
A911 CA, 1930 JD,
1932 TC, 1936 QQ,
1937 VB, 1950 BP1 | named_after=[[Baden]] | mp_category=[[main-belt]] | epoch=31 July 2016 ([[Julian day|JD]] 2457600.5) | semimajor={{Convert|3.13407|AU|Gm|abbr=on}} | perihelion={{Convert|2.63157|AU|Gm|abbr=on}} | aphelion={{Convert|3.63658|AU|Gm|abbr=on|lk=on}} | eccentricity=0.16034 | period=5.55 [[Julian year (astronomy)|yr]] (2026.6 [[Julian year (astronomy)|d]]) | inclination=3.77185° | asc_node=353.594° | arg_peri=20.1707° | mean_anomaly=133.985[[Degree (angle)|°]] | dimensions={{val|78.17|1.9|ul=km}}
78 km | mass= | density=~1.4 g/cm³ | rotation={{Convert|8.192|h|d|abbr=on|lk=on}}
0.415 d | spectral_type=[[C-type asteroid]] | abs_magnitude=9.46 | albedo={{val|0.0475|0.002}}
0.0475 | mean_motion={{Deg2DMS|0.177640|sup=ms}} / day | orbit_ref={{Cite web |url=http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=333;cad=1 |title=333 Badenia (1892 A) |work=[[JPL Small-Body Database]] |publisher=[[NASA]]/[[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] |access-date=11 May 2016}} | observation_arc=123.64 yr (45160 d) | uncertainty=0 }} '''Badenia''' ({{IPAc-en|b|ə|ˈ|d|iː|n|i|ə}} {{respell|bə|DEE|nee-ə}}; [[minor planet designation]]: '''333 Badenia''') is a large [[C-type asteroid|C-type]] (carbonaceous-type) [[asteroid]] in the outer [[asteroid belt]]. It was discovered by [[Max Wolf]] on 22 August 1892 in [[Heidelberg]]. It was the first asteroid to receive a temporary designation. ==References== {{Reflist|refs= {{cite web|url=http://www.psi.edu/pds/archive/astdata04/simps04/diamalb.tab |title=Supplemental IRAS Minor Planet Survey |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20060623213811/http://www.psi.edu/pds/archive/astdata04/simps04/diamalb.tab |archivedate=2006-06-23 |df= }} {{cite web|url=http://www.psi.edu/pds/archive/lc.html |title=PDS lightcurve data |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20060614093519/http://www.psi.edu/pds/archive/lc.html |archivedate=2006-06-14 |df= }} {{cite journal |author=G. A. Krasinsky |display-authors=etal |title=Hidden Mass in the Asteroid Belt |journal=Icarus |volume=158 |page=98 |date=2002 |doi=10.1006/icar.2002.6837|bibcode = 2002Icar..158...98K }} }} == External links == * {{AstDys|333}} * {{JPL small body}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2018}} {{Minor planets navigator |332 Siri |number=333 |334 Chicago}} {{Small Solar System bodies}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Badenia}} [[Category:Background asteroids|000333]] [[Category:Numbered minor planets|000333]] [[Category:Discoveries by Max Wolf]] [[Category:Minor planets named for places]] [[Category:Named minor planets]] [[Category:C-type asteroids (Tholen)|000333]] [[Category:Astronomical objects discovered in 1892|18920822]] {{C-beltasteroid-stub}}

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/121.218.82.102|121.218.82.102]] ([[User talk:121.218.82.102|talk]]) to last revision by InternetArchiveBot. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{about|a man-made structure intended for human use or occupation|the act of making buildings|Construction|structures not intended for human use|Nonbuilding structure|other uses|Building (disambiguation)}} {{Redirect|Edifice|the brand of watches by Casio|Casio Edifice}} {{technical reasons|Building #19|the store chain|Building 19}} [[File:Saint Sava Cathedral.JPG|thumb|[[Church of Saint Sava]], building in [[Belgrade]], [[Serbia]]]] [[File:Shaolinsi.JPG|thumb|A [[Shaolin Monastery]] building in [[China]]]] A '''building,''' or '''edifice,''' is a [[Built structure|structure]] with a [[roof]] and<ref name="Egenhofer" /> [[wall]]s standing more or less permanently in one place, such as a [[house]] or [[factory]].<ref name="Egenhofer"/> Buildings come in a variety of sizes, shapes, and functions, and have been adapted throughout history for a wide number of factors, from [[building material]]s available, to weather conditions, land prices, ground conditions, specific uses, and aesthetic reasons. To better understand the term ''building'' compare the list of [[nonbuilding structure]]s.
Buildings serve several societal needs – primarily as shelter from weather, security, living space, privacy, to store belongings, and to comfortably live and work. A building as a shelter represents a physical division of the [[:Category:Human habitats|human habitat]] (a place of comfort and safety) and the ''outside'' (a place that at times may be harsh and harmful).
Ever since the first [[cave painting]]s, buildings have also become objects or canvasses of much artistic expression. In recent years, interest in [[sustainable]] planning and building practices has also become an intentional part of the design process of many new buildings.
== Definitions == [[File:SkyBridgeMunich.jpg|thumb|right|A building and [[Skyway|skybridge]] in [[Munich]], [[Germany]]]] [[File:Rotundan - Hellerup-2000.jpg|thumb|''The Rotunda'' in [[Hellerup]], [[Denmark]], a cylindric building made in steel frame and aluminum]] [[File:Courtyard of the Great Mosque of Kairouan.jpg|thumb|right|Example of a religious building: the [[Mosque of Uqba|Great Mosque of Kairouan]] (also called the Mosque of Uqba), founded in 670, dates in its present state principally from the 9th century. The [[Mosque of Uqba|Great Mosque of Kairouan]] is located in the city of [[Kairouan]], [[Tunisia]].]] [[File:Da Vinci building (at the left), in Mendoza, Argentina. Considered one of the 1000 architectures of the Americas..JPG|thumb|upright|Da Vinci building (at the left), in [[Mendoza, Argentina]]. Considered one of the 1000 architectures of the Americas.]]
The word ''building'' is both a noun and a verb: the structure itself and the act of making it. As a noun, a building is 'a structure that has a roof and walls and stands more or less permanently in one place';<ref name="Egenhofer">{{cite book|author=Max J. Egenhofer|title=Geographic Information Science: Second International Conference, GIScience 2002, Boulder, CO, USA, September 25–28, 2002. Proceedings|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kH8gcJvVWfIC&pg=PA110|year=2002|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|isbn=978-3-540-44253-0|page=110}}</ref> "there was a three-storey building on the corner"; "it was an imposing edifice". In the broadest interpretation a [[fence]] or wall is a building.<ref>Building def. 2. Whitney, William Dwight, and Benjamin E. Smith. ''The Century dictionary and cyclopedia''. vol. 1. New York: Century Co., 1901. 712. Print.</ref> However, the word ''structure'' is used more broadly than ''building'' including natural and man-made formations<ref>Structure. def. 2. ''Merriam-Webster's dictionary of synonyms: a dictionary of discriminated synonyms with antonyms and analogous and contrasted words''.. Springfield, Mass: Merriam-Webster, 1984. 787. Print.</ref> and does not necessarily have walls. Structure is more likely to be used for a fence. [[Russell Sturgis|Sturgis' Dictionary]] included that "[building] differs from [[architecture]] in excluding all idea of artistic treatment; and it differs from [[construction]] in the idea of excluding scientific or highly skilful treatment."<ref>Building. def 1. Sturgis, Russell. ''A dictionary of architecture and building: biographical, historical, and descriptive''. vol. 1. New York: The Macmillan Co. ;, 1901. 2236. Print.</ref> As a verb, building is the act of construction.
''Structural height'' in technical usage is the height to the highest architectural detail on building from street-level. Depending on how they are classified, spires and masts may or may not be included in this height. Spires and masts used as antennas are not generally included. The definition of a ''low-rise vs. a high-rise'' building is a matter of debate, but generally three storeys or less is considered low-rise.<ref>Paul Francis Wendt and Alan Robert Cerf (1979), ''Real estate investment analysis and taxation'', McGraw-Hill, p. 210</ref>
== History == {{see also|History of architecture}} A report by [[Shinichi Fujimura]] of a shelter built 500 000 years ago<ref>{{cite news |title=World's oldest building discovered |work=BBC News |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sci/tech/662794.stm |date=2000-03-01 |accessdate=2010-01-02 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090215075027/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sci/tech/662794.stm |archivedate=2009-02-15 |df= }}</ref> is doubtful since Fujimura was later found to have faked many of his findings.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Peter Hadfield|title=Fraud means Japan must rewrite its history|journal=[[New Scientist]]|date=Nov 18, 2000|page=6|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg16822650.900-fraud-means-japan-must-rewrite-its-history.html|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129031947/http://www.newscientist.com/article/mg16822650.900-fraud-means-japan-must-rewrite-its-history.html|archivedate=2014-11-29|df=}}</ref> Supposed remains of huts found at the Terra Amata site in [[Nice]] purportedly dating from 200 000 to 400 000 years ago<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Peter Hadfield|title=Gimme shelter|journal=New Scientist|date=Mar 4, 2000|page=4|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg16522280.300-gimme-shelter.html#.U_YZXaPylrU|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150509130251/http://www.newscientist.com/article/mg16522280.300-gimme-shelter.html#.U_YZXaPylrU|archivedate=2015-05-09|df=}}</ref> have also been called into question. (See [[Terra Amata (archaeological site)|Terra Amata]].) There is clear evidence of homebuilding from around 18 000 BC.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Rob Dunn|authorlink1=Robert Dunn (biologist)|journal=New Scientist|date=Aug 23, 2014|pages=34–37|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg22329830.500-meet-the-lodgers-wildlife-in-the-great-indoors.html?full=true|title=Meet the lodgers: Wildlife in the great indoors|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129031849/http://www.newscientist.com/article/mg22329830.500-meet-the-lodgers-wildlife-in-the-great-indoors.html?full=true|archivedate=2014-11-29|df=}}</ref> Buildings became common during the Neolithic (see [[Neolithic architecture]]).
== Types == {{Main|List of building types}} [[File:Marburg, Fachwerkhaus von 1321 (2).jpg|thumb|A [[Timber framing|timber-framed house]] in [[Marburg]], [[Germany]]]] [[File:Tenements in Bruntsfield, Edinburgh.jpg|thumb|A block of tenements (apartments) in Bruntsfield, Edinburgh, Scotland]]
=== Residential === {{main|List of human habitation forms}}
Single-family residential buildings are most often called [[house]]s or [[home]]s. Residential buildings containing more than one dwelling unit are called a [[Duplex (building)|duplex]], [[apartment]] building to differentiate them from 'individual' houses. A [[condominium]] is an apartment that the occupant owns rather than rents. Houses may also be built in pairs ([[semi-detached]]), in terraces where all but two of the houses have others either side; apartments may be built round courtyards or as rectangular blocks surrounded by a piece of ground of varying sizes. Houses which were built as a single dwelling may later be divided into apartments or [[bedsitter]]s; they may also be converted to another use e.g. an office or a shop.
Building types may range from [[Hut (dwelling)|hut]]s to multimillion-dollar high-rise [[apartment block]]s able to house thousands of people. Increasing settlement density in buildings (and smaller distances between buildings) is usually a response to high ground prices resulting from many people wanting to live close to work or similar attractors. Other common [[building material]]s are brick, concrete or combinations of either of these with stone.
Residential buildings have different names for their use depending if they are seasonal include [[holiday cottage]] (vacation home) or [[timeshare]]; size such as a [[cottage]] or [[great house]]; value such as a [[shack]] or [[mansion]]; manner of construction such as a [[log home]] or [[mobile home]]; proximity to the ground such as [[Earth sheltering|earth sheltered]] house, [[stilt house]], or [[tree house]]. Also if the residents are in need of special care such as a [[nursing home]], [[orphanage]] or [[prison]]; or in group housing like [[barracks]] or [[dormitory|dormitories]].
Historically many people lived in communal buildings called [[longhouse]]s, smaller dwellings called [[pit-house]]s and houses combined with barns sometimes called [[housebarn]]s.
Buildings are defined to be substantial, permanent structures so other dwelling forms such as [[houseboat]]s, [[yurt]]s, and [[motorhome]]s are [[dwelling]]s but not buildings.
=== Multi-storey === A multi-storey is a building that has multiple floors. Sydney is a city with many multi story buildings: One suburb which has been notorious for poor construction is Lane Cove. Many overseas investors have been sucked in a and bought poorly built buildings.
=== Complex === Sometimes a group of inter-related (and possibly inter-connected) builds are referred to as a complex – for example a ''[[housing complex]]'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lincolnshirelive.co.uk/plans-to-convert-former-housing-complex-into-flats/story-30042482-detail/story.html|title=plans to convert housing complex|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170110125715/http://www.lincolnshirelive.co.uk/plans-to-convert-former-housing-complex-into-flats/story-30042482-detail/story.html#|archivedate=2017-01-10|df=|access-date=2017-02-23}}</ref> ''educational complex'',<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.isye.gatech.edu/about/maps-directions/isye-building-complex|title=isye building complex|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170103001851/https://www.isye.gatech.edu/about/maps-directions/isye-building-complex|archivedate=2017-01-03|df=}}</ref> ''hospital complex'', etc.
== Creation == The practice of designing, constructing, and operating buildings is most usually a collective effort of different groups of [[professional]]s and [[Tradesperson|trades]]. Depending on the size, complexity, and purpose of a particular building project, the project team may include:
* A [[real estate developer]] who secures [[funding]] for the project; * One or more financial institutions or other investors that provide the funding * Local planning and code authorities * A [[Quantity surveyor|Surveyor]] who performs an ALTA/ACSM and construction surveys throughout the project; * [[construction management|Construction manager]]s who coordinate the effort of different groups of project participants; * Licensed [[architect]]s and [[Architectural engineering|engineers]] who provide [[building design]] and prepare construction [[document]]s; * The principal design Engineering disciplines which would normally include the following professionals: Civil, Structural, Mechanical building services or HVAC (heating Ventilation and Air Conditioning) Electrical Building Services, Plumbing and drainage. Also other possible design Engineer specialists may be involved such as Fire (prevention), Acoustic, facade engineers, building physics, Telecomms, AV (Audio Visual), BMS (Building Management Systems) Automatic controls etc. These design Engineers also prepare construction documents which are issued to specialist contractors to obtain a price for the works and to follow for the installations. * [[Landscape architect]]s; * [[Interior design]]ers; * Other consultants; * [[General contractor|Contractor]]s who provide [[construction]] services and install building systems such as [[HVAC|climate control]], [[Electrician|electrical]], [[plumbing]], [[Painter and decorator|Decoration]], [[fire protection]], [[security]] and [[telecommunications]]; * Marketing or [[leasing]] agents; * [[facility management|Facility managers]] who are responsible for operating the building.
Regardless of their size or intended use, all buildings in the US must comply with [[zoning ordinance]]s, [[building code]]s and other regulations such as [[fire code]]s, [[life safety code]]s and related standards.
Vehicles—such as [[Trailer (vehicle)|trailers]], [[Travel trailer|caravans]], [[ship]]s and passenger [[aircraft]]—are treated as "buildings" for life safety purposes.
=== Ownership and funding === * [[Mortgage loan]] * [[Real estate developer]]
== Building services ==
=== Physical plant === {{Main|Physical plant}} [[File:The BB&T Building in Macon, Georgia.jpg|thumb|upright|The BB&T Building in [[Macon, Georgia]] is constructed of [[aluminum]].]] Any building requires a certain general amount of internal infrastructure to function, which includes such elements like heating / cooling, power and telecommunications, water and wastewater etc. Especially in [[commercial building]]s (such as offices or factories), these can be extremely intricate systems taking up large amounts of space (sometimes located in separate areas or double floors / false ceilings) and constitute a big part of the regular maintenance required.
=== Conveying systems ===
Systems for [[transport]] of people within buildings:
* [[Elevator]] * [[Escalator]] * [[Moving sidewalk]] (horizontal and inclined)
Systems for transport of people between interconnected buildings:
* [[Skyway]] * [[Underground city]]
== Building damage == [[Image:Fire inside an abandoned convent in Massueville, Quebec, Canada.jpg|thumb|A building in [[Massueville]], [[Quebec]], [[Canada]] engulfed by [[fire]]]]
Buildings may be damaged during the construction of the building or during maintenance. There are several other reasons behind building damage like accidents<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pb.unimelb.edu.au/emergency/emergencies/internal/buildingdamage.html |title=Building Damage |publisher=Pb.unimelb.edu.au |date= |accessdate=2014-08-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140214231334/http://www.pb.unimelb.edu.au/emergency/emergencies/internal/buildingdamage.html |archivedate=2014-02-14 |df= }}</ref> such as storms, explosions, subsidence caused by mining, water withdrawal<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bru|first=G.|last2=Herrera|first2=G.|last3=Tomás|first3=R.|last4=Duro|first4=J.|last5=Vega|first5=R. De la|last6=Mulas|first6=J.|date=2013-02-01|title=Control of deformation of buildings affected by subsidence using persistent scatterer interferometry|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/15732479.2010.519710|journal=Structure and Infrastructure Engineering|volume=9|issue=2|pages=188–200|doi=10.1080/15732479.2010.519710|issn=1573-2479}}</ref> or poor foundations and landslides.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Soldato|first=Matteo Del|last2=Bianchini|first2=Silvia|last3=Calcaterra|first3=Domenico|last4=Vita|first4=Pantaleone De|last5=Martire|first5=Diego Di|last6=Tomás|first6=Roberto|last7=Casagli|first7=Nicola|date=2017-07-12|title=A new approach for landslide-induced damage assessment|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/19475705.2017.1347896|journal=Geomatics, Natural Hazards and Risk|volume=0|issue=0|pages=1–14|doi=10.1080/19475705.2017.1347896|issn=1947-5705}}</ref> Buildings also may suffer from [[fire damage]]<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Brotóns|first=V.|last2=Tomás|first2=R.|last3=Ivorra|first3=S.|last4=Alarcón|first4=J. C.|date=2013-12-17|title=Temperature influence on the physical and mechanical properties of a porous rock: San Julian's calcarenite|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S001379521300286X|journal=Engineering Geology|volume=167|issue=Supplement C|pages=117–127|doi=10.1016/j.enggeo.2013.10.012}}</ref> and flooding in special circumstances. They may also become dilapidated through lack of proper maintenance or alteration work improperly carried out.
== See also == {{Portal|Architecture}} {{Div col}} * [[Autonomous building]] * [[Commercial modular construction]] * [[Earthquake engineering]] * [[Float glass]] * [[Green building]] * [[Hurricane-proof building]] * [[List of buildings and structures]] * [[List of largest buildings in the world]] * [[List of tallest buildings in the world]] * [[Natural building]] * [[Natural disaster]] and [[earthquake]] * [[Skyscraper]] * [[Steel building]] * [[Tent]] {{div col end}} <!-- please keep entries in alphabetical order -->

revision.text:
{{italic title}} [[Image:CosmographiaeIntroductio1.jpg|130 px|left|thumb|Title page of ''Cosmographiae Introductio'']] '''''Cosmographiae Introductio''''' ("Introduction to [[Cosmography]]"; [[Saint-Dié-des-Vosges|Saint-Dié]], 1507) was a book published in 1507 to accompany [[Martin Waldseemüller]]'s printed globe and wall-map (''[[Universalis Cosmographia]]''), which were the first appearance of the name '[[Americas|America]]'. Waldseemüller’s maps and book, along with his 1513 edition of [[Ptolemy]]’s ''[[Geographia (Ptolemy)|Geography]]'', were very influential and widely copied at the time.
[[Image:Cosmographiae Introductio America Reference.jpg|300 px|right|thumb|That part of the page of the 1507 (September) edition of the ''Cosmographiae Introductio'' in which the name of America is proposed for the New World. <small>From ''Narrative and critical history of America, Volume 2'' by Justin Winsor.</small>]]
It is widely held to have been written by [[Matthias Ringmann]] although some historians attribute it to Waldseemüller himself. The book includes the reason for using the name America in the wall map and the globe, and contains a Latin translation of the four journeys of [[Amerigo Vespucci]] as an appendix.
The full title of the book is: ''Cosmographiae introductio cum quibusdam geometriae ac astronomiae principiis ad eam rem necessariis. Insuper quatuor Americi Vespucii navigationes. Universalis Cosmographiae descriptio tam in solido quam plano, eis etiam insertis, quae Ptholomaeo ignota a nuperis reperta sunt.''
(translation: ''Introduction to Cosmography With Certain Necessary Principles of Geometry and Astronomy To which are added The Four Voyages of Amerigo Vespucci A Representation of the Entire World, both in the Solid and Projected on the Plane, Including also lands which were Unknown to Ptolemy, and have been Recently Discovered'')<ref>{{cite book |title=The Cosmographiæ introductio of Martin Waldseemüller in facsimile, followed by the Four voyages of Amerigo Vespucci, with their translation into English |url= https://archive.org/details/cosmographiintr00waldgoog|accessdate=2011-06-14 |year=1907 |editor= Charles G. Herbermann|publisher=The U.S. Catholic Historical Society |location=New York }}. Alternative translations have been proposed e.g. John Hessler, 2008.</ref>
[[Image:Waldseemuller map 2.jpg|thumb|250 px|''Universalis Cosmographia'' (map of 1507)]] The map of the world in 1507, entitled ''Universalis cosmographia secundum Ptholomaei traditionem et Americi Vespucii aliorumque lustrationes'', was published in an edition of 1000 copies, of which it seems only a single copy survives. The surviving copy was found in the library of Prince von Waldburg-Wolfegg-Waldsee in the Castle of [[Wolfegg]] in [[Württemberg]]. It was bought by the [[Library of Congress]] in 2001. This preservation seems to be due the several sheets being bound into a single cover by the cartographer, [[Johannes Schöner]].
The map consists of twelve sections printed from woodcuts combined with metal types, each measuring 18 x 24.5 inches (46 x 62 cm). Each section is one of four, that form one of three zones. The map uses a modified Ptolemaic coniform [[Map projection|projection]] with curved meridians to depict the entire surface of the Earth.
== References == {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{commonsinline|Cosmographia}} * [http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.gmd/g3200.ct000725C Waldseemüller's map] at the Library of Congress (includes downloadable digital image) * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080401105907/http://www.afoldgomb.hu/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=81&Itemid=47 Digital reconstruction of Waldseemüller's globe, 1507-2007] (animation)
[[Category:1507 books]] [[Category:Americas]] [[Category:Cartography]] [[Category:Geography books]]

{{expand list|date=August 2012}} This is a list of the '''bishops of Nin''', named after the town of [[Nin, Croatia]]. The Bishopric was most likely founded in the middle of the 9th century.[[#Fine-1991|Fine, 1991]], p. 254[http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/diocese/dn532.html "Diocese of Nona (Nin)"] ''[[Catholic-Hierarchy.org]]''. David M. Cheney. Retrieved October 7, 2016[http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/former/t1277.htm "Titular Episcopal See of Nin"] ''GCatholic.org''. Gabriel Chow. Retrieved October 7, 2016 ==List== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Bishop ! Office ! Notes |- | Theodosius || 879 || Listed by Daniele Farlati, Pius Basilius Gams, Carlo F. Bianchi, Ivan A. Gurato and the official Catholic schematisms.[[#Strika-2007|Strika, 2007]] |- | Alfredus || c. 890 || |- | [[Gregory of Nin|Gregorius]]
[[File:Grgur Ninski.jpg|50px]] || c. 900–929 || Gregory was the bishop of Nin and as such was under strong protection of King Tomislav. At the Synod in 925, held in Split, Gregory lost to the Archbishop of Split, he was offered the Sisak Bishopric, but he refused. After the conclusions of the first Synod Gregory complained again in 927/8 but was rejected and his Nin Bishopric was abolished, Gregory himself being sent off to the Skradin Bishopric, after which he disappears from the annals of history. {{citation needed|date=August 2012}} |- | colspan=3 |
Abolished |- | Andreas || c. 1050–1072 || |- | Forminus || fl. 1075 || |- | Gregorius || fl. 1104 || |- | Rodanus || fl. 1163 || |- | Matthaeus || 1170–1194 || |- | Ioannes || c. 1206 || |- | B. || 1229 [[#Hcma|''Hierarchia catholica medii aevi'']] || |- | S.Janson || 1230, 1241 || |- | Ioannes || 1253, 1258 || |- | Stephanus || 1272 || |- | Marcellus || 1288 || |- | Marcus || 1291 [[#Vidović-1996|Vidović 1996]], p. 537 || |- | Ioannes || 1318? || |- | Natalis || 1328 || |- | Georgius || ? || |- | ? || || |- | Juraj Divnić
"Juraj the Dalmatian" || end of 15th century || He was one of the more important Catholic bishops of Croatian origin in his time. He was born in Šibenik, and was part of the known Divnić family, which settled in Šibenik in the 14th century from Skradin, and had likely settled there from Bosnia earlier.{{citation|title=Zbornik radova o Šimunu Kožičiću Benji|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3uWfAAAAMAAJ&q=Juraj+Divnić|page=186|quote=Jedan od značajnih biskupa hrvatskoga roda iz toga doba bio je Juraj Divnić, Šibenčanin, iz poznate obitelji Divnića, koja se doselila u Šibenik u 14. stoljeću iz Skradina, a tamo još ranije, vjerojatno iz Bosne.3}} Bishop Juraj wrote Pope Alexander VI about the catastrophe right after the [[Battle of Krbava]]. |- | Horatius Belloti Venetus O. M. Conv. || 1592–1602 [[#Vidović-1996|Vidović 1996]], p. 538 || |- | Blasius Mandevius || 1602–1645 || |- | Simeon Diphnicus || 1646–1649 || |- | [[Georgius Georgiceo]] || 1649–1653 [http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/bishop/bgiorgic.html "Bishop Giorgio Giorgicci"] ''[[Catholic-Hierarchy.org]]''. David M. Cheney. Retrieved October 29, 2016 || |- | Franciscus Andronicus || 1653–1666 || |- | Franciscus Grassi || 1667–1677 || |- | Ioannes Burgofortis ([[Giovanni Borgoforte]]) || 1677–1687 || |- | Ioannes Vusius ([[Giovanni Vusich]]) || 1688–1689 || |- | [[Georgius Parchich]] || 1690–1703 || On 20 April 1693, he sent a report to the Congregation that there were 5486 Roman Catholics and 7363 Orthodox Serbs in his Bishopric. In the territory of his bishopric there was also a Serbian episcope. The Roman Catholics had 21 priests, while the Orthodox had 15. Bishop Georgius said that he worked to [[Eastern Catholic Churches#.22Uniate.22|Uniate the Orthodox]], preaching for them and teaching them the faith and the true, Catholic teachings. On 1 June 1696, he mentions that thanks to his efforts the population of the village of Poločnik denounced the "Schismatic wrongs" – the Orthodox faith, and accepted the Roman faith. {{citation needed|date=August 2012}} |- | Martinus Dragolius (Dragolovich) || 1703–1708 || |- | Ioannes Manola || 1709–1711 || |- | Antonius Rosignoli || 1713–1715 || |- | Nicolaus Drasich || 1716–1720 || |- | Bernardus Dominicus Leoni || 1722–1727 || |- | Ioannes Andreas Balbi || 1728–1732 || |- | Hieronvmus Fonda || 1733–1738 || |- | Ioannes Fridericus Orsini Rosa || 1738–1742 || |- | Thomas Nechich || 1743–1754 || |- | Antonius Tripcovich || 1754–1771 || |- |} ==References== {{reflist}} ===Sources=== *{{cite book | ref = Vidović-1996 | title=Povijest crkve u Hrvata|author=Mile Vidović|publisher=Crkva u svijetu|year=1996|isbn= 9789536151158|language=Croatian|pages=-537-}} *{{cite book | ref = Hcma | title=Hierarchia catholica medii aevi: A pontificatu Clementis PP. VIII (1592) usque ad pontificatum Alexandri PP. VII (1667)}} *{{cite book|title=Hierarchia catholica medii aevi: 1667-1730}} *{{cite journal | ref = Strika-2007 | url = http://hrcak.srce.hr/index.php?show=clanak&id_clanak_jezik=42240 | language = Croatian | journal = Radovi / Institute for Historical Sciences of the Croatian Academy of Sciences and Arts in Zadar | number = 49 |date=December 2007 | title = "Catalogus episcoporum ecclesiae Nonensis" zadarskog kanonika Ivana A. Gurata | trans-title = "Catalogus episcoporum ecclesiae Nonensis" of the Zadar Canon Ivan A. Gurato | author = Zvjezdan Strika}} * {{cite book | ref = Fine-1991 | first = John Van Antwerp | last = Fine | title = The Early Medieval Balkans: A Critical Survey from the Sixth to the Late Twelfth Century | publisher = University of Michigan Press | year = 1991 | location = Ann Arbor | isbn = 978-0-472-08149-3 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Y0NBxG9Id58C}} ==External links== * {{cite web | url = http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/diocese/dn532.html | publisher = David M. Cheney, Catholic-Hierarchy | title = Diocese of Nona (Nin) - Dioecesis Nonensis - Suppressed | accessdate = 2012-08-22}} [[Category:Catholic Church in Croatia]] [[Category:Roman Catholic bishops by diocese|Nin]] [[Category:Lists of bishops|Nin]] [[Category:Zadar County]] [[Category:Former dioceses in Europe|Nin]] [[Category:History of Dalmatia]] [[Category:Croatia-related lists|Bishops of Nin]]

The localities and neighborhoods of [[Hyderabad]] have a unique oral history, since the time of the [[Qutb Shahi dynasty]], over 400 years ago, and they are named after various people and things.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/934278764|title=Ḥaidarābād, muḥalle, galī, kūce = Hyderabad, mohalle, gali, kooche|last=1937-|first=Varmā, Ānand Rāj,|last2=1937-|first2=ورما، آنند راج،,|isbn=9788170547389|location=New Delhi|oclc=934278764}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/Hyderabad/a-rich-repertoire-of-hyderabadi-naamaan/article4412089.ece|title=A rich repertoire of Hyderabadi naamaan|last=Ifthekhar|first=J. S.|date=2013-02-13|work=The Hindu|access-date=2018-07-21|language=en-IN|issn=0971-751X}}</ref> Some are named after a major building or structure in the locality, ([[Falaknuma Palace|Falaknuma]], Koti, Lal Darwaza) others named for individuals. The names are mostly in [[Telugu language|Telugu]] and [[Urdu]], the major languages of the city.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thenewsminute.com/article/begums-mahbubs-and-shers-stories-narrated-hyderabads-neighbourhood-names-58293|title=Of Begums, Mahbubs and Shers: The stories narrated by Hyderabad's neighbourhood names|date=2017-03-08|work=The News Minute|access-date=2018-11-23}}</ref> This is a list of localities, neighborhoods and streets of [[Hyderabad]] and their etymology.
* [[A.C. Guards]] - stands for African Cavalry Guards; named after the African personal bodyguards of the [[Nizam of Hyderabad|Nizam]]; it is the area where they used to reside.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://www.eth.mpg.de/cms/en/publications/books/054.html|title=An African Indian Community in Hyderabad|author=Ababu Minda Yimene|publisher=Göttingen: Cuvillier|year=2004|isbn=3-86537-206-6}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/hyderabad/Names-of-city-localities-hark-back-to-a-forgotten-era/articleshow/12191550.cms|title=Names of city localities hark back to a forgotten era - Times of India|work=The Times of India|access-date=2018-07-21}}</ref> * [[Afzal Gunj]] - named after the fifth [[Nizam of Hyderabad|Nizam]], [[Afzal ad-Dawlah, Asaf Jah V|Afzal ad-Dawlah]]. * [[A. S. Rao Nagar|A.S. Rao Nagar]] - named after Dr. [[Ayyagari Sambasiva Rao]], the founder of the nearby [[Electronics Corporation of India Limited|ECIL]]. * [[Banjara Hills]] - named by [[Mehdi Nawaz Jung]] after the [[Banjara]] community, its original residents.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thenewsminute.com/article/man-who-gave-hyderabad-its-banjara-hills-nawab-mehdi-nawaz-jung-34143|title=The man who gave Hyderabad its 'Banjara Hills', Nawab Mehdi Nawaz Jung|date=2015-09-09|work=The News Minute|access-date=2018-07-21}}</ref> * [[Barkas, Hyderabad|Barkas]] - a corrupted form of Barracks; the area housed the military barracks of the [[Nizam of Hyderabad|Nizam]]<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.knowap.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=54:a-history-behind-street-names-of-hyderabad-a-secunderabad&catid=14:cover-features&Itemid=69|title=A History behind Street Names of Hyderabad & Secunderabad|last=Administrator|website=www.knowap.com|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-07-21}}</ref> * [[Basheerbagh|Bashirbagh]] - literally "Bashir's garden" in [[Urdu]]; named after [[Nawab Asman Jah Bahadur|Nawab Bashir-ud-Doula]], where [[Basheer Bagh Palace|his palace]] used to stand.<ref name=":0" /> *[[Begum Bazaar|Begum Bazar]], - named after ''Humda Begum'', wife of the [[Nizam Ali Khan, Asaf Jah II|second Nizam]]; It is believed she gifted the land to the merchants of the city.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.indianmirror.com/tourism/indian-bazaars/Begum-Bazaar-Hyderabad.html|title=BEGUM BAZAAR HYDERABAD-INDIANMIRROR|website=www.indianmirror.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-07-21}}</ref> *[[Chaderghat]] - "''Chader"'' literally means "White Sheet" in [[Urdu]]; <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thehansindia.com/posts/index/Hans/2016-01-19/Yeh-Humara-Shehar-Chaderghat-/201182|title=Yeh Humara Shehar: Chaderghat|website=The Hans India|language=en|access-date=2018-07-22}}</ref><ref name=":0" /> * [[Dar-ul-Shifa]] - literally "House of Healing" in [[Urdu]]; named after a historic hospital in the area.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.deccanchronicle.com/nation/in-other-news/081016/hyderabad-421-year-old-historic-place-1st-hospital-of-asia-neglect-ails.html|title=Hyderabad: Neglect ails 1st hospital of Asia|date=2016-10-08|work=Deccan Chronicle|access-date=2018-07-21|language=en}}</ref> * [[Falaknuma Palace|Falaknuma]] - literally "Mirror of the Sky" in [[Urdu]]; named after the [[Falaknuma Palace]]. * [[Hayathnagar]] - named after ''Hayath Bakshi Begum,'' daughter of [[Muhammad Quli Qutb Shah]]; this is the area where she built [[Hayat Bakshi Mosque|a mosque]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thenewsminute.com/article/photo-essay-hayath-bakshi-begum-hand-king-three-times-over-42086|title=Photo essay: Hayath Bakshi Begum- The hand of the king, three times over|date=2016-04-23|work=The News Minute|access-date=2018-07-21}}</ref> * [[Himayatnagar, Hyderabad|Himayatnagar]] - named after the son of the [[Mir Osman Ali Khan|last Nizam]], Prince [[Azam Jah]], or [[Azam Jah|Mir Himayat Ali Khan]].<ref name=":0" /> *[[HITEC City]] - abbreviated form of Hyderabad Information Technology and Engineering Consultancy City. * [[Khairtabad]] - named after ''Khairunnisa Begum'', daughter of [[Sultan Muhammad Qutb Shah]]; this is the area where she built [[Khairtabad Mosque|a mosque]]. * [[Koti, Hyderabad|Koti]] - literally "mansion" in Urdu; named after the [[British Residency, Hyderabad|Koti Residency]], which used to be located here. * [[Lal Darwaza]] - literally "Red Door" in [[Urdu]]; named after a Red Gateway that used to exist in the area.<ref name=":1" /> * [[Mahatma Gandhi Road]] - named after [[Mahatma Gandhi]] after independence; previously used to be called James Street, named after [[James Achilles Kirkpatrick|Major James Achilles Kirkpatrick]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bl.uk/onlinegallery/onlineex/apac/photocoll/j/019pho0000430s6u00026000.html|title=James Street, Secunderabad.|last=Wright|first=Colin|website=www.bl.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-07-21}}</ref> *[[Malakpet]] - named after ''Malik Yaqoub'', a servant of [[Abdullah Qutb Shah]], where he used to reside.<ref name=":1" /> *[[Masab Tank]] - a corruption of ''Ma Saheba Tank'', after a tank which itself was named after ''Hayath Bakshi Begum'' (called ''Ma Saheba'' affectionately), a [[Qutb Shahi dynasty|Qutb Shahi]] princess. * [[Mehdipatnam]] - named after [[Mehdi Nawaz Jung]], a politician, bureaucrat and eminent personality of [[Hyderabad]]. * [[Moazzam Jahi Market]] - named after the son of the [[Mir Osman Ali Khan|last Nizam]], Prince [[Moazzam Jah]]. * [[Moula-Ali|Moula Ali]] - named after the [[Moula Ali hill|Moula Ali Dargah]] (a [[dargah]], or shrine dedicated to [[Ali]]), which is located here. * [[Musheerabad]] - named after [[Arastu Jah|Nawab Arastu Jah Mushir-ul-Mulk]], who served as [[List of Prime Ministers of Hyderabad State|Prime Minister of Hyderabad]].<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thehindu.com/society/history-and-culture/the-musheerabad-badi-masjid-narrates-a-lesser-known-chapter-in-hyderabads-history/article19523546.ece|title=There lies a forgotten story|last=Nanisetti|first=Serish|date=2017-08-19|work=The Hindu|access-date=2018-07-21|language=en-IN|issn=0971-751X}}</ref> * [[Nampally, Hyderabad|Nampally]] - named after ''Nekh Nam Khan'', a ''Diwan'' of Hyderabad during the [[Qutb Shahi dynasty|Qutb Shahi]] era.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.in/books/about/Hyderabad_400_Years_1591_1991.html?id=sVWqQgAACAAJ&redir_esc=y|title=Hyderabad 400 Years, 1591-1991|last=Alikhan|first=Raza|date=1991|publisher=Zenith Services|language=en}}</ref> * [[Nayapul]] - literally "New Bridge" in [[Urdu]]; named for a bridge built over the [[Musi River (India)|River Musi]] located here. * [[Purana pul|Puranapul]] - literally "Old Bridge" in [[Urdu]]; named for the 400-year-old bridge over [[Musi River (India)|River Musi]] located here. *[[P.V. Narasimha Rao Expressway]], named after [[P. V. Narasimha Rao]], a former [[Prime Minister of India]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ndtv.com/india-news/hyderabad-gets-indias-longest-flyover-403367|title=Hyderabad gets India's longest flyover|work=NDTV.com|access-date=2018-07-21}}</ref> * [[Sanjeeva Reddy Nagar]] - named after [[Neelam Sanjiva Reddy]], former President of India. * [[Saroornagar]] - named after ''Suroor Afza Bai'', wife of [[Prime Minister of Hyderabad]] [[Arastu Jah]].<ref name=":0" /> * [[Secunderabad]] - named after the third [[Nizam of Hyderabad|Nizam]], [[Mir Akbar Ali Khan Sikander Jah, Asaf Jah III|Sikandar Jah]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.amazon.in/Lashkar-Story-Secunderabad-Narendra-Luther/dp/8190175211|title=Lashkar: The Story Of Secunderabad|last=Luther|first=Narendra|date=2010|publisher=Kalakriti Art Gallery|isbn=9788190175210|edition=1st|location=Hyderabad|language=English}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
{{Neighborhoods of Hyderabad}} [[Category:Neighbourhoods in Hyderabad, India]] [[Category:Hyderabad, India-related lists]] [[Category:Etymologies of geographic names]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 3 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.5.4)

revision.text:
{{Infobox fictional location | name = Fawcett City | image = | image_size = | caption = | blank_label = [[:Category:Comics publishing companies|Publisher]] | blank_data = [[Fawcett Comics]], then [[DC Comics]] | first = | creators = | type = | people = [[Captain Marvel (DC Comics)|Captain Marvel]]
[[Marvel Family]]
[[Bulletman and Bulletgirl]]
[[Spy Smasher]]
[[Ibis the Invincible]]
[[Mister Scarlet]]
[[Pinky the Whiz Kid]]
[[Minute-Man]] | races = | locations = }} '''Fawcett City''' is a [[fictional]] [[city]] appearing in stories published by [[DC Comics]]. ==Overview== First mentioned in ''[[Crisis on Infinite Earths]]'' #7 in 1985''Crisis oInfinitete Earths'' #7 (1985). DC Comics. and later formally established in [[Jerry Ordway]]'s ''[[The Power of Shazam!]]'' graphic novel in 1994, it served as the home base of [[Captain Marvel (DC Comics)|Captain Marvel]] and the [[Marvel Family]] during the 1990s and 2000s. Its name is derived from the original publishers of Captain Marvel comics, [[Fawcett Comics]]. It is also home to [[Bulletman and Bulletgirl]], [[Spy Smasher]], [[Ibis the Invincible]], [[Mister Scarlet]] and [[Pinky the Whiz Kid]] and [[Minute-Man]]; also characters from Fawcett Comics. Features of Fawcett City include [[radio]] station [[WHIZ (comics)|WHIZ]], which employs Captain Marvel's teenaged [[alter ego]] Billy Batson as an on-air and field reporter. Streets in Fawcett City have been named in honor of creators who worked on the ''Shazam!'' property over the decades, including [[Otto Binder]] (Binder Boulevard) and [[Bill Parker (comics)|Bill Parker]]. Fawcett City, like other fictional cities that appear in comics published by DC, has no exact location, besides being identified as being located in the [[Midwest]] region of the [[United States]]. However, in the 1990s series ''[[The Power of Shazam!]]'', it was suggested that it was located in [[Wisconsin]], thanks to various clues given by writer Jerry Ordway (who grew up in [[Milwaukee]]).{{cite web|title=Creator Profile: Jerry Ordway|url=http://comicartcommunity.com/2013/01/creator-profile-jerry-ordway/|website=Comic Art Community|accessdate=22 July 2016}} A ''[[Teen Titans]]'' ''Secret Files & Origins'' special, however, stated that Fawcett City was located in [[Indiana]][http://www.karridian.net/dcusa_gl.html DC Atlas - Great Lakes Region] and a map in ''JSA vs. Kobra'' #4 (November 2009) indicates that the city is in [[Minnesota]].{{cite web |url=http://www.mykey3000.com/cosmicteams/jsa/_chron/jsachron10.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-11-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100111224143/http://www.mykey3000.com/cosmicteams/jsa/_chron/jsachron10.html |archivedate=2010-01-11 |df= }} Fawcett City is also a small town compared to [[Metropolis (comics)|Metropolis]] and [[Gotham City]]. The city is distinguished in the comic stories by an old-fashioned look and feel. Despite existing in the modern world, with current technologies and events, Fawcett seems old fashioned, as if stuck in the 1940s or 1950s. This timeless feel was explained in the ''Power of Shazam!'' series as being the results of a spell cast over the city in 1955 by [[Ibis the Invincible]]. The spell was requested by the wizard [[Shazam (wizard)|Shazam]], and was said to have protected Fawcett from the influences of outside evils and slowed the passage of time. For the next forty years within the [[DC Universe]], the city existed as a time-warp of sorts to the 1950s. The spell was shown to be removed in ''Power of Shazam!'' #11 (January 1996), and Fawcett began to slowly become a more modern city, although most of its [[Art Deco]] style buildings and generally old-fashioned values remain intact. Other stories featuring the Captain Marvel/Shazam! characters were set in other locales. The Fawcett-era and 1973-1985 (pre-''[[Crisis on Infinite Earths]]'') DC-era stories were set in a [[New York City|New York]] in an alternate universe known as [[Earth-S]]. The 1987 miniseries ''Shazam! The New Beginning'' was set in [[San Francisco]], and the most recent 2012-2013 ''Shazam!'' story from the pages of ''[[Justice League]]'' was set in [[Philadelphia]]. Alternate universe versions of the Marvel Family, as depicted in ''[[The Multiversity]]'', live in Fawcett City on what is known as "[[Earth-5]]" in the DC Universe. ==Points of interest== * Beckville - A neighborhood in Fawcett City. It is named after C. C. Beck.''Power of Shazam'' Graphic Novel. DC Comics * Binder Square - Fawcett City's recreational area. * Binder Subway Station - A subway station that Billy Batson went through where he was called through a portal to the Rock of Eternity where he met Shazam.''Power of Shazam'' #18. DC Comics * Sivana Industries - A large and successful company that is owned by [[Doctor Sivana|Thaddeus Sivana]]. * [[WHIZ (comics)|WHIZ Radio]] - Fawcett City's radio station.''Whiz Comics'' #2. Fawcett Comics. ==In other media== ===Television=== * Fawcett City appears in ''[[The Kid Superpower Hour with Shazam!]]'' * Fawcett City appears in the ''[[Justice League Unlimited]]'' episode "The Clash." * Fawcett City appears in the ''[[Batman: The Brave and the Bold]]'' episode "The Power of Shazam." ===Film=== Fawcett City appears in ''[[Superman/Shazam!: The Return of Black Adam]]''. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Shazam}} {{DC Comics populated places}} [[Category:Captain Marvel (DC Comics)]] [[Category:Fictional populated places in the United States]] [[Category:DC Comics populated places]] [[Category:1994 in comics]] {{DC-Comics-stub}} {{fict-location-stub}} [[de:DC-Universum#Städte]]

page.title: Flags of the regions of Ethiopia

revision.text:
[[Ethiopia]] is currently split into nine different [[Region]]s. The [[Afar Region]], the [[Harari Region]], the [[Gambela Region]], the [[Oromia Region]], the [[Somali Region]], the [[Tigray Region]], the [[Benishangul-Gumuz Region]], the [[Amhara Region]], and the [[Southern Nations, Nationalities, and Peoples' Region]], each with their own flag.
== List == * {{Flagicon|Afar}} [[Afar Region]] <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.crwflags.com/fotw/flags/et-af.html|title=Afar (Ethiopia)|website=www.crwflags.com|access-date=2016-10-24}}</ref> (adopted in 2012) * {{Flagicon|Amhara}} [[Amhara Region]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.crwflags.com/fotw/flags/et-am.html|title=Amhara (Ethiopia)|website=www.crwflags.com|access-date=2016-10-24}}</ref> * {{Flagicon|Benishangul-Gumuz}} [[Benishangul-Gumuz Region]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.crwflags.com/fotw/flags/et-be.html|title=Benishangul/Gumuz (Ethiopia)|website=www.crwflags.com|access-date=2016-10-24}}</ref> * {{Flagicon|Gambela}} [[Gambela Region]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.crwflags.com/fotw/flags/et-ga.html|title=Gambella (Ethiopia)|website=www.crwflags.com|access-date=2016-10-24}}</ref> * {{Flagicon|Harari}} [[Harari Region]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.crwflags.com/fotw/flags/et-ha.html|title=Harari (Ethiopia)|website=www.crwflags.com|access-date=2016-10-24}}</ref> * {{Flagicon|Oromia}} [[Oromia Region]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.crwflags.com/fotw/flags/et-or.html|title=Oromiya (Ethiopia)|website=www.crwflags.com|access-date=2016-10-24}}</ref> * {{Flagicon|Somali Region}} [[Somali Region]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.crwflags.com/fotw/flags/et-so.html|title=Somali (Ethiopia)|website=www.crwflags.com|access-date=2016-10-24}}</ref> * {{Flagicon|Southern Nations, Nationalities, and Peoples' Region}} [[Southern Nations, Nationalities, and Peoples' Region]] (adopted in 1994)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.crwflags.com/fotw/flags/et-sn.html|title=Southern Nationals, Nationalities and People's Regional State (Ethiopia)|website=www.crwflags.com|access-date=2016-10-24}}</ref> * {{Flagicon|Tigray}} [[Tigray Region]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.crwflags.com/fotw/flags/et-ti.html|title=Tigray (Ethiopia)|website=www.crwflags.com|access-date=2016-10-24}}</ref> (designed in 1990)
== Gallery == <gallery> File:Flag of the Afar Region.svg |Flag of the [[Afar Region]] File:Flag_of_the_Amhara_Region.svg |Flag of the [[Amhara Region]] File:Flag of the Benishangul-Gumuz Region.svg|[[Benishangul-Gumuz Region]] File:Flag of the Gambella Region.svg |Flag of the [[Gambela Region]] File:Et harrar.png |Flag of the [[Harari Region]] File:Flag of the Oromia Region.svg |Flag of the [[Oromia Region]] File:Somalistatenewflag.jpeg |Flag of the [[Somali Region]] File:Flag_of_the_Southern_Nations,_Nationalities,_and_Peoples%27_Region.svg |Flag of the [[Southern Nations, Nationalities, and People's Region]] File:Flag_of_the_Tigray_Region.svg |Flag of the [[Tigray Region]] </gallery>
== See also == *[[Flag of Ethiopia]] *[[Regions of Ethiopia]] *[[State flag|Regional flag]]
== References == {{Reflist}}

page.title: General Assembly of Prince Edward Island

revision.text:
{{Infobox legislature | name = General Assembly of Prince Edward Island | legislature = [[65th General Assembly of Prince Edward Island]] | house_type = [[Bicameral]] (1773–1893)
[[Unicameral]] (1893–present) | houses = [[Legislative Council of Prince Edward Island|Legislative Council]] (1773–1893)
[[House of Assembly of Prince Edward Island|House of Assembly]] (1773–1893)
[[Legislative Assembly of Prince Edward Island|Legislative Assembly]]
(1893–present) | foundation = {{Start date|1773}} | session_room = 282 - Birthplace of Canada Charlottetown PEI.JPG | meeting_place = [[Province House (Prince Edward Island)|Province House]], [[Charlottetown]], [[Prince Edward Island]], [[Canada]] }} The '''General Assembly of Prince Edward Island''' is the legislature of the province of [[Prince Edward Island]], [[Canada]]. Today, the legislature is made of two elements: the [[Lieutenant Governor of Prince Edward Island]],{{Cite canlaw |short title = Legislative Assembly Act |abbr = RSPEI |year = 1988 |chapter = L-7 |section = 1 |subsection = 1 |part = |division = |schedule = |link = http://www.gov.pe.ca/law/statutes/pdf/l-07.pdf |linkloc = Legislative Counsel Office of Prince Edward Island |wikilink = |type = |amended1 = |amended2 = |amended3 = |amended4 = |amended5 = |regtitle = |regnumber = }}. and the [[unicameral]] assembly called the [[Legislative Assembly of Prince Edward Island]]. The legislature was first established in 1773. Like the Canadian federal government, Prince Edward Island uses a [[Westminster System|Westminster-style]] [[parliamentary government]], in which members are elected to the Legislative Assembly through [[List of Prince Edward Island general election|general elections]]. The party with the most seats forms Government. A [[Premier of Prince Edward Island]] and [[Executive Council of Prince Edward Island]] are formally appointed by the Lieutenant Governor in the name of The Queen. The premier acts as Prince Edward Island's [[head of government]], while the [[Queen of Canada]] acts as [[head of state]]. The legislature was originally bicameral, with an upper house called the [[Legislative Council of Prince Edward Island]] and a lower house called the [[House of Assembly of Prince Edward Island]]. The Legislative Council also held executive power until 1839. In 1893 the houses were amalgamated into the [[Legislative Assembly of Prince Edward Island]]. Unlike other provinces that eliminated their upper house, the assembly continued to have a distinction between members elected as Councillors and members elected as Assemblymen. This distinction was eliminated in 1996, giving all members the title [[Member of the Legislative Assembly]], upon the change from dual ridings (two members per district) to single ridings (one member per district) in the Legislative Assembly. ==List of Assemblies== {|class="wikitable" !align="right"| Assembly !align="right"| Period !align="right"| Election !align="right"|[[Dissolution of parliament|Dissolution]] |- |[[65th General Assembly of Prince Edward Island]] |2015–present |[[Prince Edward Island general election, 2015|May 4, 2015]] | |- |[[64th General Assembly of Prince Edward Island]] |2011 - 100 % (2012 est.) |- | '''Irrigated Land:''' ||0 km2 |- | '''[[Climate]]''': || [[tropical]]; moderated by northeast trade winds |- | '''[[Terrain]]''': || flat and low-lying [[island]] of [[coral]] and [[limestone]] |- | '''Natural resources''' || [[salt]], [[fish]], [[lobster]] |- | '''Natural hazards''' || [[hurricane]]s, [[tropical storm]]s (June to November) |- | '''Environmental issues''' || low [[water]] supplies |} This article describes the '''[[geography]] of [[Anguilla]]'''. Anguilla is an island in the [[Leeward Islands]], which lies between the Caribbean Sea in the west and the open Atlantic Ocean in the east. It is a long, flat, dry/wet, scrub-covered [[coral island]], south and east of [[Puerto Rico]] and north of the [[Windward Islands|Windward]] chain. One of the [[Renaissance Islands]], it is separated from the [[British Virgin Islands]] by the [[Anegada Passage]]. The island has no significant elevations with its terrain consisting entirely of beaches, dunes, and low limestone bluffs. ==Hills== Anguilla’s highest elevation, [[Crocus Hill]], is {{convert|73|m|ft|0|abbr=on}}. Crocus Hill is among the cliffs that line the northern shore. ==Coastline== The numerous bays, including Barnes, Little, Rendezvous, Shoal, and Road Bays, lure many vacationers to this tropical island. The coast and the beautiful, pristine beaches are integral to the [[Tourism of Anguilla|tourism]]-based economy of Anguilla. Because of Anguilla’s warm climate, the beaches can be used year-round. == Statistics == '''Location:''' Caribbean, island in the Caribbean Sea, east of [[Puerto Rico]] '''Geographic coordinates:''' 18°15′ N, 63°10′ W '''Map references:''' Central America and the [[Caribbean]] '''Area:''' *''total:'' {{convert|91|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}} *''land:'' {{convert|91|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}} *''water:'' {{convert|0|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} '''Area — comparative:''' about half the size of [[Washington DC]] '''Land boundaries:''' 0 km '''Coastline:''' 61 km '''Maritime claims:''' *''exclusive fishing zone:'' {{convert|200|nmi|km mi|1|abbr=on|lk=in}} *''territorial sea:'' {{convert|3|nmi|km mi|1|abbr=on}} '''Climate:''' [[tropical]] moderated by northeast [[trade winds]] '''Terrain''': flat and low-lying [[island]] of [[coral]] and [[limestone]] '''Elevation extremes:''' *''lowest point:'' Caribbean Sea 0 m *''highest point:'' Crocus Hill 65 m '''Natural resources:''' [[salt]], [[fish]], [[lobster]] '''Land use:''' *''arable land:'' 0% *''permanent crops:'' 0% *''permanent pastures:'' 0% *''forests and woodland:'' 61.1% *''other:'' 38.9% (mostly rock with some commercial salt ponds) '''Irrigated land:''' 0 km2 (2012) '''Natural hazards:''' frequent hurricanes and other tropical storms (July to October) '''Environment - current issues:''' supplies of potable water sometimes cannot meet increasing demand largely because of poor distribution system. ==Islands and cays== [[File:Anguilla islands.svg|thumb|350px|Anguilla islands and cays]] The territory of Anguilla consists of the island of Anguilla itself (by far the largest), as well as numerous other islands and cays, most of which are very small and uninhabited. These include: * [[Anguillita]] * [[Blowing Rock, Anguilla|Blowing Rock]] * [[Cove Cay]] * [[Crocus Cay]] * [[Deadman's Cay]] * [[Dog Island, Anguilla|Dog Island]] * [[East Cay, Anguilla|East Cay]] * [[Little Island, Anguilla|Little Island]] * [[Little Scrub Island]] * [[Mid Cay]] * [[North Cay]] * [[Prickly Pear Cays]] * [[Rabbit Island, Anguilla|Rabbit Island]] * [[Sandy Island, Anguilla|Sandy Island]], also known as Sand Island * [[Scilly Cay]] * [[Scrub Island, Anguilla|Scrub Island]] * [[Seal Island, Anguilla|Seal Island]] * [[Sombrero, Anguilla|Sombrero]], also known as Hat Island * [[South Cay, Anguilla|South Cay]] * [[South Wager Island]] * [[West Cay]] ==Districts== Anguilla is divided into fourteen districts: {{Clear}} {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ |-bgcolor=#ACE1AF !District !data-sort-type="number"|Population (2011){{cite web|url=http://www.geopoliticalmaps.com/geopolitical-map-of-anguilla-districts.php|title=Districts of Anguilla| accessdate=2015-03-23}} |- | [[Blowing Point]]||style="text-align:right"|870 |- | [[East End, Anguilla|East End]]||style="text-align:right"| 671 |- | [[George Hill, Anguilla|George Hill]]||style="text-align:right"|879 |- | [[Island Harbour, Anguilla|Island Harbour]]||style="text-align:right"|988 |- | [[North Hill, Anguilla|North Hill]]||style="text-align:right"|464 |- | [[North Side, Anguilla|North Side]]||style="text-align:right"|1980 |- | [[Sandy Ground, Anguilla|Sandy Ground]]||style="text-align:right"|230 |- | [[Sandy Hill, Anguilla|Sandy Hill]]||style="text-align:right"|636 |- | [[South Hill, Anguilla|South Hill]]||style="text-align:right"|1722 |- | [[Stoney Ground]]||style="text-align:right"|1549 |- | [[The Farrington]]||style="text-align:right"|624 |- | [[The Quarter, Anguilla|The Quarter]]||style="text-align:right"|959 |- | [[The Valley, Anguilla|The Valley]]||style="text-align:right"|1067 |- | [[West End, Anguilla|West End]]||style="text-align:right"|813 |} ==Climate== Anguilla features a [[tropical wet and dry climate]] under the [[Köppen climate classification]]. The city has a rather dry climate, moderated by northeast [[trade wind]]s. Temperatures vary little throughout the year. Average daily maxima range from about {{convert|27|°C|°F|1|abbr=on}} in December to {{convert|30|°C|°F|abbr=on}} in July. Rainfall is erratic, averaging about {{convert|900|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} per year, the wettest months being September and October, and the driest February and March. Anguilla is vulnerable to hurricanes from June to November, peak season August to mid-October. The island suffered damage in 1995 from [[Hurricane Luis]]. {{Weather box |location = The Valley - capital of Anguilla |metric first = yes |single line = yes |Jan high C = 28 |Feb high C = 28 |Mar high C = 28 |Apr high C = 28 |May high C = 30 |Jun high C = 31 |Jul high C = 31 |Aug high C = 31 |Sep high C = 31 |Oct high C = 30 |Nov high C = 29 |Dec high C = 28 |year high C = 30 |Jan mean C = 26 |Feb mean C = 26 |Mar mean C = 26 |Apr mean C = 27 |May mean C = 27 |Jun mean C = 28 |Jul mean C = 29 |Aug mean C = 29 |Sep mean C = 29 |Oct mean C = 28 |Nov mean C = 27 |Dec mean C = 26 |year mean C = 27 |Jan low C = 23 |Feb low C = 23 |Mar low C = 23 |Apr low C = 25 |May low C = 25 |Jun low C = 26 |Jul low C = 26 |Aug low C = 26 |Sep low C = 26 |Oct low C = 26 |Nov low C = 25 |Dec low C = 24 |year low C = 23 |Jan precipitation cm = 7 |Feb precipitation cm = 4 |Mar precipitation cm = 4 |Apr precipitation cm = 7 |May precipitation cm = 9 |Jun precipitation cm = 7 |Jul precipitation cm = 8 |Aug precipitation cm = 11 |Sep precipitation cm = 11 |Oct precipitation cm = 9 |Nov precipitation cm = 11 |Dec precipitation cm = 9 |year precipitation cm = 102 |source 1 = Weatherbase{{cite web |url=http://www.weatherbase.com/weather/weatherall.php3?s=66887&refer=&units=metric |title=Weatherbase: Historical Weather for The Valley |accessdate=}} |date=August 2010 }} ==Vegetation== Anguilla’s coral and limestone terrain provide no subsistence possibilities for [[forest]]s, [[woodland]], [[pasture]]s, [[crops]], or [[arable land]]s. Its dry climate and thin soil hamper commercial agricultural development. ==See also== *{{wikiatlas|Anguilla}} == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.caribbean-on-line.com/ag/agm.shtml Caribbean-On-Line.com] provides detailed maps of Anguilla. * [http://www.statoids.com/uai.html Districts of Anguilla], Statoids.com * [http://www.gov.ai/statistics/census/images/Housing%20and%20Households.pdf Anguilla 2001 Census], Government of Anguilla {{Geography of North America}} {{Districts of Anguilla}} {{North America topic|Climate of}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Geography Of Anguilla}} [[Category:Geography of Anguilla| ]]

[[File:Un-guinea-bissau.png|thumb|550px|A map of Guinea Bissau]] [[File:LocationGuineaBissau.svg|thumb|Location of Guinea Bissau]]
This article describes the '''geography of [[Guinea-Bissau]]'''.
== Terrain and ecology == [[Image:Guinea-Bissau Topography.png|thumb|350px|Guinea-Bissau's topography.]]
The terrain of Guinea-Bissau is mostly low coastal plain with swamps of [[Guinean mangroves]] rising to [[Guinean forest-savanna mosaic]] in the east.<ref name=fact />
The lowest point on Guinea-Bissau is at sea level at the Atlantic Ocean.<ref name="fact"/> The highest point on Guinea-Bissau is 300 metres above sea level at an unnamed location in the eastern part of the country.<ref name="fact"/>
Natural resources found in Guinea-Bissau include fish, [[timber]], [[phosphates]], [[bauxite]], clay, [[granite]], limestone and unexploited deposits of [[petroleum]].<ref name="fact"/> 10.67% of the land is arable and 235.6 square kilometres is irrigated.<ref name="fact"/>
Natural hazards include a hot, dry, dusty [[harmattan]] haze that may reduce visibility during the dry season and brush fires.<ref name="fact"/> Severe environmental issues include [[deforestation]]; [[soil erosion]]; [[overgrazing]] and [[overfishing]].<ref name="fact"/>
Near the Senegal border there have been historic sightings of the [[painted hunting dog]], ''Lycaon pictus'', but that [[endangered]] canid may now be [[Local extinction|extirpated]] in that locale.<ref>C. Michael Hogan. 2009. [https://web.archive.org/web/20101209234758/http://globaltwitcher.auderis.se/artspec_information.asp?thingid=35993 ''Painted Hunting Dog: Lycaon pictus'', GlobalTwitcher.com, ed. N. Stromberg] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101209234758/http://globaltwitcher.auderis.se/artspec_information.asp?thingid=35993 |date=December 9, 2010 }}</ref>
== Climate ==
Guinea-Bissau's [[tropical climate|climate is tropical]]. This means it is generally hot and humid. It has a [[monsoon]]al-type rainy season (June to November) with southwesterly winds and a dry season (December to May) with northeasterly harmattan winds.<ref name=fact>[https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/pu.html U.S. Central Intelligence Agency. ''World Factbook'']</ref>
Guinea-Bissau is warm all year around and there is little temperature fluctuation; it averages {{convert|26.3|C|F}}. The average rainfall for the capital city Bissau is {{convert|2024|mm|in|1}} although this is almost entirely accounted for during the rainy season which falls between June and September/October. From December through April, the country receives very little rainfall.
[[File:Climate diagram of Bissau, Guinea-Bissau.svg|centre|600px]]
== Bissagos Islands == {{Main|Bissagos Islands}}
== Information from the CIA World Factbook == [[Image:Paesaggio Guinea-Bissau0001.JPG|thumb|300px|Typical scenery in Guinea-Bissau.]] [[File:20130613-DSC_9133_(9291669831)_(2).jpg|thumb|300px|right|Eastern Guinea-Bissau [[Table (landform)|High plain mountains]] near the border with [[Guinea]]]] [[File:Praia_de_Ofir,_Bolama,_Guiné-Bissau_–_2018-03-03_–_DSCN1195.jpg|thumb|300px|right|Ofir beach, [[Bolama Region|Bolama]], Bijagós Islands, Guinea-Bissau]]
; [[Location (geography)|Location]]: : Western [[Africa]], bordering the North [[Atlantic Ocean]], between [[Guinea]] and [[Senegal]] ; [[Geographic coordinates]]: : {{coord|12|00|N|15|00|W|type:country}} ; Map references ; Area: :* Total: 36,125 km<sup>2</sup> :* Land: 28,120 km<sup>2</sup> :* Water: 8,005 km<sup>2</sup> ; Area—comparative: : Slightly less than three times the size of [[Connecticut]] ; Land boundaries: :* Total: 762 km :* Border countries: [[Guinea]] 421 km, [[Senegal]] 341 km ; Coastline: : 350 km ; Maritime claims: :* Territorial sea: {{convert|12|nmi|km mi|1|abbr=on}} :* Exclusive [[economic zone]]: {{convert|200|nmi|km mi|1|abbr=on|lk=in}} ; Terrain: : Mostly low coastal plain rising to [[savanna]] in east ; Elevation extremes: :* Lowest point: Atlantic Ocean 0 m :* Highest point: Unnamed location in the northeast corner of the country 300 m ; Natural resources: : [[Fish]], [[timber]], [[phosphates]], [[bauxite]], unexploited deposits of [[petroleum]] ; Land use: :* Arable land: 10.67% :* Permanent crops: 8.89% :* Other: 80.44% (2012 est.) ; Irrigated land: : 223.6 km<sup>2</sup> (2003) ; Total renewable water resources: : 31 km<sup>3</sup> ; Freshwater withdrawal (domestic/industrial/agricultural): :* Total: 0.18 km<sup>3</sup>/yr (18%/6%/76%) :* Per capita: 135.7 m<sup>3</sup>/yr (2005) ; Natural hazards: : Hot, dry, dusty harmattan haze may reduce visibility during dry season; brush fires ; Environment—current issues: : [[Deforestation]]; [[soil erosion]]; [[overgrazing]]; [[overfishing]] ; Environment—international agreements: :* Party to: [[Biodiversity]], [[United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change|Climate Change]], [[Desertification]], [[Endangered Species]], Hazardous Wastes, [[Law of the Sea]], Ozone Layer Protection, [[Wetlands]] :* Signed, but not ratified: None of the selected agreements<ref name=fact />
== Extreme points ==
This is a list of the extreme points of [[Guinea-Bissau]], the points that are farther north, south, east or west than any other location.
* Northernmost point – the northern section of the border with [[Senegal]]* * Easternmost point – unnamed location on the border with [[Guinea]] immediately south-west of the Guinean village of [[Sofan, Gabú|Sofan]], [[Gabú Region]] * Southernmost point – unnamed headland on Ilha Cataque, [[Tombali Region]] * Westernmost point - Cap Roxo at the point where the border with [[Senegal]] enters the [[Atlantic Ocean]], [[Cacheu Region]] * *''Note: Guinea-Bissau does not have a northern-most point, the border here being formed by a straight horizontal line''
==See also== *[[Guinea-Bissau]]
==Line notes== {{Reflist}}
==References== * C. Michael Hogan. 2009. [https://web.archive.org/web/20101209234758/http://globaltwitcher.auderis.se/artspec_information.asp?thingid=35993 ''Painted Hunting Dog: Lycaon pictus'', GlobalTwitcher.com, ed. N. Stromberg] * U.S. Central Intelligence Agency. [https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/pu.html]
{{Guinea-Bissau topics}} {{Geography of Africa}} {{Africa topic|Climate of}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Geography Of Guinea-Bissau}} [[Category:Geography of Guinea-Bissau| ]]

{{For|another Swiss theodolite inventor with a similar name|Heinrich von Wild}} [[File:Wild Heinrich und Liliy.jpg|thumb|Heinrich and Lilly Wild (1900)]] '''Heinrich Wild''' ([[Mitlödi]], [[Canton of Glarus]], November 15, 1877 – [[Baden, Switzerland|Baden]], [[Switzerland]], December 26, 1951) was a [[Swiss people|Swiss]] [[inventor]], [[designer]] and [[Entrepreneur|founder]] of [[Wild Heerbrugg]].
==Biography== [[File:Survey Instrument designs by H.Wild.jpg|thumb]] At 15 years of age, Wild became an apprentice with the engineer Legler in [[Glarus]] ([[hydraulic engineer]] for the [[Linth]] River). He bought a small [[theodolite]], and after a short time independently made expanded measurements of the flow of the river Linth. Later Wild joined the Geometerschule (geometer school) at [[Winterthur]] and came in 1899 as a trainee to the Landestopographie ([[Swisstopo]] is a popular designation for the Swiss Federal Office of [[Topography]]) in [[Bern]]. Due to his bad experiences with the high mountain triangulation with a theodolite of conventional design, he tried in 1905 to design a new theodolite with rotable circle with coincidence circle-readings.
In 1907 he left the Landestopographie and moved to [[Jena]], [[Germany]], where he joined the company [[Carl Zeiss]] to build up a new department for producing geodetic instruments. He began with the development of [[levelling instrument]]s and designed later also a new theodolite, the Th I.
In 1921 Wild returned to [[Switzerland]] and founded with Dr. R. Helbling, who operated a measurement office, and with the politician Jacob Schmidheiny, the company Heinrich Wild, Werkstätte für Feinmechanik und Optik (later known as [[Wild Heerbrugg]], Wild-Leitz AG,<ref>"Wild Heerbrugg und Leitz Wetzlar mit gemeinsamem Namen." New name Wild-Leitz AG from 1989. Neue Zürcher Zeitung, December 28, 1988, p. 30</ref> [[Leica Geosystems]], [[Leica Microsystems]], [[Leica Camera]]).
At this time he developed the first versions of the famous universal theodolite Wild T series and also the stereo autograph Wild A1 for aerial [[photo interpretation]],<ref>K. Hildebrand and R. Schlienger: "Scharfer Blick von oben." [[Neue Zürcher Zeitung]], April 24, 1984, p. 69</ref> besides a number of other measurement instruments.
It may be perhaps typical for the inventors like Wild that he worried little about the financial condition of his company{{Citation needed|date=April 2010}}, and this ended finally with the consequence that Wild separated in 1932 from the company he founded, in order to be able to work as a freelance technical designer and inventor. He continued designing up until his death in 1951. Among his designs were the legendary{{Citation needed|date=April 2010}} DK1, DKM1, DM2, DKM2, and DKM3, for Kern & Co, Aarau, besides other things.
The [[ETH Zurich]] honored him with the title Dr. honoris causa in 1930.
His biography was published in the [[Historical Dictionary of Switzerland]]<ref>[http://www.hls-dhs-dss.ch/textes/d/D31162.php Wolfgang Göldi: "Heinrich Wild". Historisches Lexikon der Schweiz, Biography (in German)]</ref> as well as by the ETHZ.<ref>[http://www.sgc.ethz.ch/sgc-volumes/sgk-31.pdf Biography of Heinrich Wild, Swiss Geodetic Commission, published by ETHZ (in German)]</ref>
==External links== * [http://www.wild-heerbrugg.com Virtuelles Archiv von Wild Heerbrugg AG] {{Hexagon AB}} {{Ernst Leitz GmbH}}
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Wild, Heinrich}} [[Category:Swiss inventors]] [[Category:1877 births]] [[Category:1951 deaths]] [[Category:Leica people]] [[Category:Surveying]]

{{refimprove|date=June 2016}} {{Infobox meteorite |Name= Hoba |Image = Hoba meteorite00.jpg |Image_caption= Size relative to a human being |Lat_Long={{coord|19|35|32|S|17|56|01|E|display=inline,title}} |Type= Iron |Class=12 }} The '''Hoba'''<ref name=database>{{metbull|11890|Hoba}}</ref> ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|h|oʊ|b|ə}} {{respell|HOH|bə}}) [[meteorite]], short for '''Hoba West''', is a meteorite that lies on the farm of the same name, not far from [[Grootfontein]], in the [[Otjozondjupa Region]] of [[Namibia]]. It has been uncovered but, because of its large mass, has never been moved from where it fell. The main mass is estimated at more than 60 tonnes,<ref name=database/> making it the largest known [[meteorite]] (as a single piece)<ref>{{Cite book |title=Meteorites and their parent planets |last=McSween |first= Harry |date=1999 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |isbn=0521583039 |edition=2nd |location=Cambridge |oclc=39210190}}</ref> and larger than the 37-tonne fragment of the [[Campo del Cielo]]. It is also the most massive naturally occurring piece of [[iron]] (actually ferronickel) known on Earth's surface. The name "Hoba" comes from [[Khoekhoegowab]] word meaning "gift".<ref>{{Cite book|title=Place Names of Namibia A Historical Dictionary|last=Cassidy|first=Joseph|publisher=Macmillan Education Namibia Publishers (Pty) Ltd|year=2009|isbn=978-99916-0-654-5|location=Windhoek|pages=37}}</ref>
==Impact== The Hoba meteorite impact is thought to have occurred more recently than 80,000 years ago. It is inferred<ref>Field Guide to Meteors and Meteorites - O. Richard Norton and Lawrence Chitwood. Springer Science + Business Media 2008, {{ISBN|978-1-84800-156-5}}</ref> that the [[Earth's atmosphere]] slowed the object to the point that it impacted the surface at [[terminal velocity]], thereby remaining intact and causing little excavation. Assuming a drag coefficient of about 1.3, the meteor would have been slowed to about {{convert|720|mph|km/s|sigfig=2}} from its speed on entering the Earth's atmosphere, typically in excess of 10 km/s for similar objects. The meteorite is unusual in that it is flat on both major surfaces.
==Discovery== The Hoba meteorite left no preserved [[Impact crater|crater]] and its discovery was a chance event. The owner of the land, Jacobus Hermanus Brits, encountered the object while ploughing one of his fields with an [[cattle|ox]]. During this task, he heard a loud metallic scratching sound and the plough came to an abrupt halt. The obstruction was excavated, identified as a meteorite and described by Mr. Brits, whose report was published in 1920 and can be viewed at the [[Grootfontein]] Museum in Namibia.
[[Friedrich Wilhelm Kegel]] took the first published photograph of the Hoba meteorite.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Spencer |first1=L. J. |last2=Hey |first2=M. H. |title=Hoba (South-West Africa), the largest known meteorite |journal=The Mineralogical Magazine and Journal of the Mineralogic Society |url=https://rruff.info/doclib/MinMag/Volume_23/23-136-1.pdf |date=March 1932 |volume=XXIII<!--23--> |number=136 |page=4 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161215172158/http://rruff.info/doclib/MinMag/Volume_23/23-136-1.pdf |archivedate=2016-12-15}}</ref>
==Description and composition== Hoba is a tabloid body of metal, measuring {{convert|2.7|*|2.7|*|0.9|m|ft}}. In 1920 its mass was estimated at 66 tonnes. Erosion, scientific sampling and vandalism reduced its bulk over the years. The remaining mass is estimated at just over 60 tonnes. The meteorite is composed of about 84% iron and 16% [[nickel]], with traces of [[cobalt]]. It is classified as an [[ataxite]] [[iron meteorite]] belonging to the nickel-rich chemical class [[IVB meteorites|IVB]]. A crust of iron [[hydroxide]]s is locally present on the surface, owing to weathering.
==Modern history== In an attempt to control vandalism and with permission from Mrs. O. Scheel, owner of the farm at the time, the government of [[South West Africa]] (now Namibia) on March 15, 1955, declared the Hoba meteorite to be a national monument.<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Geochimica et Cosmochimica Acta |volume=31 |issue=9 |date=September 1967 |page=1470 |first=M.F. |last=Comerford |title=Comparative erosion rates of stone and iron meteorites under small-particle bombardment |doi=10.1016/0016-7037(67)90021-X |publisher=Elsevier Science, New York |issn=0016-7037|bibcode=1967GeCoA..31.1457C}}</ref> In 1979 the proclamation was changed to include not only the meteorite but also 25 m x 25 m land on which it is situated.<ref name=Voigt>{{Cite book | title=National Monuments in Namibia: An Inventory of Proclaimed National Monuments in the Republic of Namibia | last=Voigt | first=Andreas | publisher=Gamsberg Macmillan | year=2004 | pages=4-5 | isbn= 9991605932 | url=https://books.google.com.na/books?id=h0h0AAAAMAAJ}}</ref> In 1985 [[Rössing]] Uranium Ltd. made resources and funds available to the Namibian government to provide additional protection against vandalism. In 1987 Mr. J. Engelbrecht, the owner of Hoba West farm, donated the meteorite and the site where it lies to the state for educational purposes. Later that year, the government opened a tourist centre at the site.<ref name=Voigt/> As a result of these developments, vandalism of the Hoba meteorite has ceased and it is now visited by thousands of tourists every year.
<gallery mode=packed height=150px> File:Hoba Meteorite.jpg|The Hoba meteorite before the construction of the circular steps. File:Hoba meteorite (15682150765).jpg|The meteorite in 2014 after becoming a tourist attraction. File:Tatton Park 2016 205 (4x3).jpg|Part of the Hoba meteorite at [[Tatton Park]] in England. </gallery> ==See also== {{Commons category|Hoba meteorite}} * [[Glossary of meteoritics]] * [[List of largest meteorites on Earth]]
==Notes and references== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== *''[[Universe (book)|Universe: The Definitive Visual Dictionary]]'', Robert Dinwiddie, DK Adult Publishing, (2005), pg. 223. * {{cite journal |first=P. E. |last=Spargo |title=The History of the Hoba Meteorite Part I: Nature and Discovery |journal=Monthly Notes of the Astronomical Society of Southern Africa |volume=67 |issue=5/6 |year=2008 |pages=85–94 |url=http://www.mnassa.org.za/html/Jun2008/2008MNASSA..67..Jun..85.pdf |access-date=2018-07-24|bibcode=2008MNSSA..67...85S }} * {{cite journal |first=P. E. |last=Spargo |title=The History of the Hoba Meteorite Part II: The News Spreads |journal=Monthly Notes of the Astronomical Society of Southern Africa |volume=67 |issue=9/10 |year=2008 |pages=166–177 |url=http://www.mnassa.org.za/html/Oct2008/2008MNASSA..67..Oct..166.pdf |access-date=2018-07-24|bibcode=2008MNSSA..67..166S }} * {{cite journal |first=P. E. |last=Spargo |title=The History of the Hoba Meteorite Part III: Known and Loved by All |journal=Monthly Notes of the Astronomical Society of Southern Africa |volume=67 |issue=11/12 |year=2008 |pages=202–211 |url=http://www.mnassa.org.za/html/Dec2008/2008MNASSA..67..Dec..202.pdf |access-date=2018-07-24|bibcode=2008MNSSA..67..202S }}
